Policy for the Management of Allergy Status / MSBPO-18020 / version 1.0

Introduction

A number of incidents reported locally, nationally and internationally, illustrate serious harm, in some cases fatal, has occurred to patients who have been prescribed, dispensed and administered drugs to which they have had a pre-existing allergic response.
Scope

This policy covers all patients admitted to hospital either as an elective or emergency admission. Any patient admitted on an electronic prescribing (EP) system or issued with a paper Drug Prescription Chart and Administration Record (AKA: “drug chart”) should have the “allergy status” section of the chart filled in.
Purpose:

To ensure we manage patients with a known allergy / adverse drug reaction (ADR) to medication, in an efficient and structured manner, to minimise risk to the patient. Serious harm has occurred when patients have been prescribed / dispensed / administered drugs, to which they have a pre-existing allergy or known serious reaction. This policy is necessary to ensure that medication allergy and adverse drug reaction (ADR) status of all patients is confirmed, as soon as possible following admission.

Patients also have allergies and sensitivities to other substances such as surgical equipment (e.g. latex) and foods. It is important that these are treated the same as any drug allergy / sensitivity to avoid exposure to the patient whilst under our care.

This policy seeks to give a clear and robust system on how to identify patients' allergy / ADR status, how and where to document this, use of the Trust wristband and the responsibilities of health care professionals. It is recommended in the Department of Health report, Building a Safer NHS for Patients- Improving Medication Safety March 2004 that Trusts should implement a written standard for the documentation of drug allergies.
Definitions

table_items.text: Drug allergy is a hypersensitivity condition of the body against a certain drug manifesting most frequently in various skin reactions, bronchospasm and oedema, while the most severe form of allergy is anaphylactic shock, which is an acute life- threatening allergic reaction connected with oedema of the respiratory tract.

A defined health record of a patients current allergies or sensitivities or a clear statement that there are no such allergies or sensitivities. This will be dated and state the nature of any such allergies.
Drug sensitivity is typically an intolerance, which is often a milder, non-immune-mediated reaction, and does not depend on prior exposure.

Adverse Drug Reaction. A response to a drug that is noxious and unintended and occurs at doses normally used in man for the prophylaxis, diagnosis or therapy of disease, or for modification of physiological function" (World Health Organisation definition).

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Roles and Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) Site Clinical Governance Committee (CGC) (or equivalent) Responsible for:
Receive exception reporting from MOC/MMC and determine appropriate action with directorates/divisions as appropriate
Site/MSB Medicines Optimisation Committee (MOC) / Medicines Management
Committee (MMC) (or equivalent)
Responsible for:
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy.
Where necessary the MOC/MMC will escalate concerns to the Site Director of Nursing or Medical Director as appropriate.
Site Medicines Use and Safety Action Group (MUSAG) (or equivalent)
Responsible for:
Monitoring this policy through incident reports
Reporting and exception reporting any relevant audits and action plans to MOC/MMC in an appropriate and timely manner.
Site Professional Nursing and Midwifery Forum (PNMF) (or equivalent) Responsible for:
Ensuring any Nursing or Midwifery professional issues related to the administration of medicines and allergy status is managed and actions taken.
Following up any actions identified from audits undertaken to ward level.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust Duties Are:
Chief Executive
As the Trust Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for:
Ensuring the MSB group of hospitals has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Nurse/Director of Nursing
Responsible for:
Ensuring the system of recording allergy status and identification (as per this policy and relevant site policies) is maintained and measured in accordance with Trust governance arrangements
Site Medical Director
Responsible for:
Ensuring any Medical staff professional issues related to the prescribing of medicines and allergy status is managed and actions taken.
Site Pharmacy Head of Department
Responsible for:
Ensuring any Pharmacy staff or other allied health professional issues related to the prescribing of medicines and allergy status is managed and actions taken.
Liaising with the relevant allied health professional lead, where appropriate, to facilitate this.
Prescribers (including non-medial Prescribers), Administering staff (i.e. Registered Nurse/Midwife) and Registered Pharmacy staff
Jointly responsible for:
Existing allergies & sensitivities:

Ensuring that any new patient has their allergy status documented on their drug chart (i.e. allergy and type of reaction caused, if known). This must also be documented in the patients' medical notes (i.e. in the appropriate place in the admission documentation/proforma).

Documenting on the ePrescribing drug chart the allergy status under “Patient Allergy” or double checking the existing information. Where paper drug charts are used, allergies should be documented in the allergy status box and the entry should be signed and dated with a bleep number.
Ensuring allergies are clear and the type of reaction is recorded, and clarifying this
where needed without delay.
New allergies & sensitivities:

Update the patient's drug chart and medical records with details of any allergy that occurs whilst they are an inpatient. The same applies if an existing allergy becomes apparent in the period after admission (i.e. via old notes etc.). The documentation must detail the type of reaction.
Prescriber
Responsible for (in addition to joint responsibilities above):
Ensuring that they consult the allergy status before prescribing any medication for a patient.
Ensure they do not prescribe any medication to a patient where the allergy status has not been documented unless the patient's clinical condition demands it.
Ensure the allergy status is always transcribed in full on all subsequent drug charts used during the patient's admission.
New allergies & sensitivities:
Ensuring new allergies are transcribed onto the discharge summary with the type of reaction to inform the GP.
Registered Nurse / Midwife
Responsible for (in addition to joint responsibilities above):
Existing allergies & sensitivities:
Ensuring that the patient's allergy status is documented in the relevant paperwork etc. where they are involved in the admission process.

Ensuring each patient under their care has the appropriate wristband(s) attached in accordance with the Site Patient ID policy. Any patient with any documented allergy (drug /food/dressing etc.) should ensure that the patient has red ID wristbands attached as opposed to the standard white ones.
Confirming that any new patient under their care has their allergy status documented on their drug chart, and taking appropriate actions as detailed in this policy.

Not administering any medication to a patient with no documented allergy status, either on the drug charts or in the medical notes (unless the patient's medical condition demands it). The appropriate documentation should be sought ASAP and updated by the registrant, where possible. Where a patient requires urgent medical attention any vital medication should be given, even if the allergy status of the patient is unknown.
New allergies & sensitivities:

Ensuring that a new set of red wristbands are issued to the patient and the white ones removed if a new allergy occurs. The same applies if an existing allergy becomes apparent in the period after admission (i.e. via old notes etc).
Pharmacy Staff
Responsible for:

Not supplying medication for an individual patient where the allergy status is not documented on the drug chart. Where a supply of medication is requested against a drug chart with no allergy status medical team or ward staff will be contacted in order to verify allergy status. The only exception to this is again for patients whose medical attention requires urgent treatment, and neonates.
Making arrangement for confirming and documenting allergy status with the relevant medical team, if attending the ward.
Supporting the accuracy of allergy status documentation as part of the medicines reconciliation process, including alerting prescribers and updating of documentation as appropriate.
Determining Allergy Status

Where possible the patient should be asked their allergy status. Where this is not a reliable source of information other sources should be consulted (please refer to the Site Policy for Medicines Reconciliation for a guide).
JAC ePrescribing (SUH site only) will prompt the user every time the drug chart is accessed where allergy status is not documented.
Appropriate sources of information include:
Patient
Healthcare records
Previous prescription charts
Patient's relative or carer
GP
Summary care record (SCR)
No Known Allergies
Patients with no known allergies must be endorsed with the statement “None Known” or “No Known Allergies” i.e. NKA.
Where ePrescribing is used the ‘No known drug allergies' button must be clicked on and therefore ‘ticked'.
Where paper drug charts are used ‘no known drug allergies', NKDA, NKA may be used in the allergy status box, signed and dated.
Neonate Allergy Status Documentation

7.1 Neonates, by their nature, do not have any allergies at birth. Allergy status on drug charts must be annotated with NKDA/NKA or ‘newborn'. This should then be updated as and if appropriate as per this policy.
Allergies Unknown

In patients where the allergy status is currently unavailable or unknown then a statement to this effect must be recorded. This must only be used where all reasonable attempts have been made at that time to establish allergy status, without success.
Where JAC ePrescribing (SUH site) is used the “Drug Allergy Status Undetermined” button must be clicked on and therefore ‘ticked'.
Where paper drug charts are used, “To Be Confirmed” or “Unknown At Present”, must be documented, along with the date, in the allergy box.
This must be followed up at the earliest opportunity, and allergy status updated with either the response for no known or known allergies/sensitivities.
Known allergies and sensitivities
Patients with a known allergy must have this documented on the drug chart with the nature of the reaction also recorded.

The drug chart also calls for “sensitivities”. This does therefore include drugs which may have caused an adverse effect i.e. diarrhoea, dizziness. These sensitivities may be significant enough to warrant avoiding a drug or drug group and must be recorded but it is vital to also record the nature of the reaction so that they can be dealt with accordingly.
Alternatively patients may have allergies to latex or shellfish. These allergies must also be recorded on the drug chart as overlooking them may have significant implications for patient safety.

The type of reaction must be documented. Some reactions may be manageable should the drug be required in future (as the only choice at that time). Alternatively the reaction may be life threatening and must never be prescribed for the patient.

In JAC ePrescribing (SUH site) allergies may be added from the patient allergy section. Drugs are prebuilt into a drop down list. Combination drugs are not listed. Therefore, where a patient is allergic to a combination product, all constituent drugs must be listed. The most common reactions are also provided in a drop down menu. Where ‘Other' is selected, the type of reaction must be recorded on ePrescribing as an ‘Allergic Reaction' note. JAC ePrescribing (SUH site) will automatically alert a prescriber with a warning should the drug be attempted to be prescribed at a later date. This MUST be actively overridden by the prescriber, therefore requiring additional thought before continuing.
Where paper charts are used, the type of reaction should be recorded next to the drug. The allergy status must be signed and dated.
10 Patient Identification Wristbands

Allergies must not be written on any wristbands. The drug chart is the approved location for documenting allergies and sensitivities. All patients with any type of allergy/sensitivity (drug, food, dressing etc.) must wear RED colour wristbands.
11 Training Requirements
No specific training requirements.

data.text: 13 Approval and Implementation

This policy has been reviewed and approved by the Medicines Optimisation/Management Groups, overseen by pharmacy, across the msb group of hospitals. This will be implemented with immediate effect from its agreement date. This document will be available electronically on the Trust intranet. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the site department of pharmacy.
